This course will provide students with an understanding of what nanotechnology is.  Students undertake studies focusing on the major themes of
Nanotechnology, e.g. bionanotechnology, nanostructured materials and
Nanoelectronics. A major component of the course is the study of nanoscience and its application in nanotechnological devices, e.g. quantum computing, DNA chips, nanogears, quantum dots, DNA sequencing, nanoparticles, and biosensors.  Students will have the opportunity to visit the NSW Nanofabrication facility, which is located on the UNSW campus.  The course is only available to students enrolled in program 3617 and cannot be used as a general education course.

This course covers the study of nanoparticles, nanostructured materials and nanoscale devices. This will be initially done by exploring the chemistry related to the synthesis and assembling of nanoparticles. The course will then progress to the discussion of technologies available for obtaining information about morphology, composition and crystallographic orientation of nanoparticles. This will be followed by the investigation of electronic and magnetic properties of nanomaterials, as well as by discussions about methods available for simulating materials at an atomic level. Finally, the course will cover the study of cutting-edge devices, such as nanopores, single-molecule biosensors and optical tweezers.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"97569eafdb399850eb6b147a3a9619e2","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment task - Materials","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"13","description":"

A quiz composing of non-trivial questions will be presented to the students. Answering to those questions in some cases involves doing a bit of research and hard-thinking. As a result, it is possible to evaluate the knowledge gathered by the students on nanomaterials as well as their problem solving and analytical skills. Quiz will be returned with comments and students will be encouraged to make appointments for discussion.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5f569eafdb399850eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"47569eafdb399850eb6b147a3a96199e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment task - Physics","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"13","description":"

The students will be asked to write a Nature News & Views style article about either a) one of the papers analysed in the course, or b) another paper prefered by the student and confirmed by the lecturer. The essay will be returned with comments and students will be encouraged to make appointments for discussion.

This 2 hours exam will compose of short answer questions. Questions will assess the knowledge of theory and application discussed in the three core components: chemistry, materials and physics.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"13569eafdb399850eb6b147a3a9619d9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"47569eafdb399850eb6b147a3a9619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"5f569eafdb399850eb6b147a3a9619db","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"9b569eafdb399850eb6b147a3a9619de","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8f569eafdb399850eb6b147a3a9619b3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab Report - Chemistry","assessment_type":{"label":"Lab work","value":"lab_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"14","description":"

Students will synthesise gold nanoparticles and explore the principle of self-assembled monolayers to prepare smart windows. Students will be marked by individual lab reports. Lab reports will be returned with comments and students will be encouraged to make appointments for discussion.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"NANO3001 - Advanced Nanomaterials","description":"

The aim of this course is to provide a detailed background in the physical principles which underpin the behaviour of materials, in particular those in nanostructured state. It will be then demonstrated how these principles are practically applied in the preparation, testing, behaviour and application of nanomaterials. Such materials are widely used in a range of applications such as sensors, biomedical coatings, high wear resistant and corrosion resistant coatings.

You will be required to undertake calculations involving the application of modern electron theory to topics covered throughout the course including
-The wave nature of electrons
-Electrical conduction in metals, semiconductors and insulators

Feedback will be given two weeks after submission of the assignment and take the form of the marked assignment, comments on how the class performed, and any common areas that were not answered correctly. Additionally, personal feedback and how each student performed may be given. A solution sheet for each assignment, showing the worked answers and relevant comments, will be uploaded onto Moodle two weeks after their submission.

The aim of this exam is to assess students’ skills in solving problems concerning introductory aspects of electron theory and its application to materials science and engineering (Parts I & II).  It will consist of a combination of multiple choice and essay-style questions involving some calculations. Any derivations will assume knowledge of the material rather than memorizing equations with relevant background equations provided.

Feedback: As the mid-term exam is the formal exam for Part 1 of the course, with the content not examinable in Part 2, students will receive their final mark.

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"NANO3002 - Nanomedicine","description":"

The aim of this course will be to introduce the significant area of Nanomedicine. Nanomedicine is already a large industry, and is rapidly expanding. As a broad example, nanomedicine relates to the delivery of pharmaceuticals by the application of functional nanomaterials, or the application (of the medicinal chemistry) of the nanomaterials themselves. This course will begin with an introduction to conventional medicinal chemistry, highlighting the chemical design and application of medicines and why new systems are constantly required. The application of nanomedicine in vitro (e.g. biosensors and diagnostic devices) and in vivo (e.g. drug delivery) will be covered. Finally, as medicinal activity is strongly correlated with toxicity, the potential toxicity of nanomaterials will be covered, including the types of evaluations that can be performed on new nanomaterials.

contentlets.description: The aim of this course will be to introduce the significant area of Nanomedicine. Nanomedicine is already a large industry, and is rapidly expanding. As a broad example, nanomedicine relates to the delivery of pharmaceuticals by the application of functional nanomaterials, or the application (of the medicinal chemistry) of the nanomaterials themselves. This course will begin with an introduction to conventional medicinal chemistry, highlighting the chemical design and application of medicines and why new systems are constantly required. The application of nanomedicine in vitro (e.g. biosensors and diagnostic devices) and in vivo (e.g. drug delivery) will be covered. Finally, as medicinal activity is strongly correlated with toxicity, the potential toxicity of nanomaterials will be covered, including the types of evaluations that can be performed on new nanomaterials.

This course requires a major piece of research to be undertaken by students in Stage 4 of the Nanoscience (Honours) program 3618. 

A range of interdisciplinary projects is offered by contributing schools - Chemistry, Physics, and Material Science  - enabling students to carry out experimental investigations in an area of Nanoscience. 

The project is year-long and contributes 36 UOC in total towards a student's program: 12 UOC per term over three terms.

Note: To be eligible for entry to this course students must be enrolled in program 3618 Nanoscience (Honours) or 3617 Nanotechnology, and have successfully completed Stages 1-3.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"900245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961946","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"80","description":"

The thesis is the major piece of work submitted at the end of the 36 UoC research project. The thesis will require clear communication of project aims, experimental design, assessment of risks, experimental results, and interpretation of results and design of subsequent experiments (where relevant).

\n

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"040245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96191e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"400245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"480245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8c0245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"940245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961942","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7ff105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research proposal","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are required to write a formal research proposal on their project.  The proposal should include a summary of background research, a clear statement of project aims, design of anticipated experiments, and an indication of anticipated outcomes.  Students will also be required to give a short oral presentation on their proposal.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"400245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961921","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"480245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a96193f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8c0245b7db391c50eb6b147a3a961923","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b7f105b7db391c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

At the conclusion of their Honours project  (i.e. near the end of the third term of enrolment), students are required to give a formal seminar.  The duration of the oral examination is up to 20 minutes, followed by a period of questions.

contentlets.description:
This course requires a major piece of research to be undertaken by students in Stage 4 of the Nanoscience (Honours) program 3618. 

A range of interdisciplinary projects is offered by contributing schools - Chemistry, Physics, and Material Science  - enabling students to carry out experimental investigations in an area of Nanoscience. 

The project is year-long and contributes 36 UOC in total towards a student's program: 12 UOC per term over three terms.

Note: To be eligible for entry to this course students must be enrolled in program 3618 Nanoscience (Honours) or 3617 Nanotechnology, and have successfully completed Stages 1-3.
contentlets.title: Nanoscience Project
